BE

The embattled FTSE-100 mining group Anglo American is drawing up plans to replace its veteran finance chief as it pursues a radical restructuring triggered by the rout in global commodity prices.

Sky News has learnt that Anglo is at the early stages of a process to identify a successor to Rene Medori, who has held the role since 2005, making him one of the longest-serving finance chiefs in Britain’s blue-chip share index.

The search for Mr Medori’s successor comes after a torrid period for Anglo as well as rival London-listed mining groups such as BHP Billiton and Glencore, which have been forced to slash their dividends as their profits have slumped.

BE

http://news.sky.co...k-new-finance-boss

BE

Which struck me as negligibly important, in the scheme of things, but apparently I'm wrong.

11:07 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 480.90, down 19.9 (-3.97%), High: 513.60, Low: 478.15, Volume: 2.17m
BE

Citi talking about trouble at the top.

BE

All of which may be a serious bit of extrapolation by a long-term seller, but let's hear them out anyway.

11:08 am
BE

It has roughly been three years since all the major miners change their CEOs and in some instances CFOs. Press reports (Bloomberg etc.) have suggested that Anglo American is now looking for a new CFO to replace Rene Medori, who has been CFO since 2005. Also, Chris Lynch, the CFO for RIO, was passed over for the CEO position and, in our opinion, may consider looking elsewhere. The question is what does this all mean. In our opinion it has been a case of musical chairs at the CEO/CFO level with the positions being filled by industry insiders. In our view the boards of the large mining companies need to be more creative and look outside the industry to drive a major change in how the companies are run and managed. Reheating former CFOs and CEOs in our view just doesn't cut it in the new commodity era that we are in. Arguably the accounts should be running the businesses rather than mining engineers. The question is whether Anglo does change its CFO and what the implications would be, the company has been vocal to say that it doesn't need to do a capital raise, which, in our view, they need to do so a new appointment may shift in this stance.

BE

The company aims to reduce its net debt to less than $10bn by the end of this year from $12.9bn at the end of 2015; with a medium term net debt target of $6bn. To achieve this Anglo targets $3-4bn of disposals and $1.9bn of cost and productivity improvements in 2016.

The company had a comfortable ~$15bn liquidity at the end of 2015 and have ~$5bn of debt maturing by 2017 which is roughly 25% of the total group debt.

We believe a CFO departure prior to the completion of the announced restructuring and disposals could become a hurdle for the company. In addition the uncertainty over a CFO change is likely to put pressure on the stock price. We maintain our Sell rating with a target price of £2.50.

BE

We rarely get overly excited about a CFO leaving, particularly if it's quite a long time before they leave. But I guess it's an argument.

BE

Transforming From A Duckling...Into A Swan Over the past 18 months, easyJet has underperformed Ryanair by c.40% and has been the worst performing European airline share price in our coverage year-to-date. easyJet has, in investors’ minds, fallen from grace as Ryanair has re-seized the initiative and reassumed its mantle as the leader in the European low-cost airline sector expansion story. Moreover, rising costs, downward-spiralling pricing, increasing competitive
capacity, high fuel-hedging, an appreciating dollar and flailing earnings’ momentum have
all weighed on easyJet’s share price. Our upgrade to Buy (with a PO of 1,800p, c.+20%
upside) challenges this negative sentiment and takes a contrarian view on topics such as
potential effects of ‘Brexit,’ near-term pricing, cost initiatives & valuation.

11:15 am
BE

Time For The Short-base To Get On Board The Alpha Plane: Our Buy case addresses the following points: 1. The direct ‘Brexit’ issues for easyJet are
likely being overemphasised; 2. easyJet’s summer capacity trends are moderating, which
could result in a potential average fare pricing uplift; 3. The upcoming summer
savings announcement will likely provide near-term share price support.

BE

Appealing Valuation, Both In Relative & Absolute Terms: Finally, easyJet’s valuation is appealing, particularly in light of the fact that we view the
company as a long-term secular winner, sector survivor and value creator. easyJet trades
on a P/E of c.10x in FY16 and c.8x in FY17, which is below the five-year historical
average of c.12x. Additionally, the company trades on an EV/CE of c.1.0x, despite
achieving, on our forecasts, an average ROCE of c.18% (in FY16-FY18) vs. an estimated
WACC of c.13%. We also note that easyJet will, on our forecasts, pay a c.4% & c.5% div.
yield in FY16 & FY17, alongside c.£500mn net cash. Upside/downside risks to our thesis
are volatility in UK/European GDP & the jet fuel price, a No/Yes vote in the EU
referendum & any sale of Sir Stelios’ stake in easyJet (e.g. potentially to a M.E. carrier).

Hang on i have a summary

PM

The consultative document Reducing variation in credit risk-weighted assets - constraints on the use of internal model approaches sets out the Committee's proposed changes to the advanced internal ratings-based approach and the foundation internal ratings-based approach.

The proposed changes include a number of complementary measures that aim to: (i) reduce the complexity of the regulatory framework and improve comparability; and (ii) address excessive variability in the capital requirements for credit risk. Specifically, the Basel Committee proposes to:

remove the option to use the IRB approaches for certain exposures, where it is judged that the model parameters cannot be estimated sufficiently reliably for regulatory capital purposes;
adopt exposure-level, model-parameter floors to ensure a minimum level of conservatism for portfolios where the IRB approaches remain available; and
provide greater specification of parameter estimation practices to reduce variability in risk-weighted assets (RWA) for portfolios where the IRB approaches remain available.

11:19 am
PM

The Committee has previously consulted on the design of aggregate capital floors based on standardised approaches and is still considering the design and calibration. This would complement the proposed constraints discussed in this consultation paper.

The final design and calibration of the proposals will be informed by a comprehensive quantitative impact study and by the Committee's aim to not significantly increase overall capital requirements.

The Committee welcomes comments from the public on all aspects of the proposals described in this document here by Friday 24 June 2016. All comments will be published on the Bank for International Settlements website unless a respondent specifically requests confidential treatment.

PM

Suggesting getting rid of bank's internal credit assessments -- of borrowers

PM

Basel restrict internal models - Basel4 First read

11:20 am
PM

■ The Basel Committee (BCBS) on March 24 proposed to restrict banks' options for using internal models, when calculating credit risk, see bis.org/bcbs/publ/d362.htm. The proposal's key elements are; (1) To remove the IRB model option for bank and large corporate exposures (

EUR50bn in assets), which instead will be subject to the Standard Approach. Removal of internal model option for CVA risk and a floor for Counterparty risk models. (2) To set floors on model parameters (key changes; min PD increase from 3bp to 5bp; LGD is set to 25% for unsec corporate and 0-20% for secured exposure; min EAD include 50% weight for off-balance sheet exposures). (3) To constrain the parameter estimation in banks internal models (key changes; PD estimate should include 10% weight on downturn years and a constraint on banks' LGD estimates). The BCBS state that it considers a new Basel1 floor of 60-90%. The consultation ends 24 June and BCBS aim to finalise rules by end-2016.

■ Conflicting messages on Basel 4. The BCBS aim to ensure a minimum level of conservatism in banks' models, but state that proposals should '…not significantly increase overall capital requirements.' The proposals are far-reaching and to some extent contradict other senior policy makers' statements; Mark Carney, governor at BoE, stated 'There is no Basel IV', 1 December, 2015 (Bbrg). Until investors get clarity, the market could read the proposals as a negative event. As a positive, the BCBS did not propose changes to sovereign RWs and state the review is 'careful, gradual and holistic'. We argue, meaningfully higher sovereign RWs are unlikely.
■ First read – potential RWA impact could be manageable. Given that the proposal impact c.80% of bank RWAs, a full scale study is difficult. Our first read of the three key elements above, suggest the impact could be meaningful, but manageable. We estimate the removal of the IRB option for bank/large corporate exposures implies c2.0% RWA inflation (c.30bp off CET1). High impact in Nordics; SHB (UP) c.120bp off CET1, SWED (N) c.100bp. Lower impact for Nordea (N) and SEB (UP) c.50bp and for UBS (N), LLOY (not covered) and ING (not covered) of 35-40bp. For Intesa (OP), BARC (not covered) and SAN (N), impact look miniscule. Removing internal model option for CVA, impact IB oriented banks (but CVA is only c.2-4% of total RWAs). The increase in min PD from 3bp to 5bp, mathematically increase RWs by c.50%, but impact banks with ultra-low RW mortgages (but Nordic/Belgium already have 25% mortgage floors). The min LGD of 25% for corporate book, look manageable as majority of banks already use higher numbers (sector average c.36%, according to BCBS).

11:34 am
BE

LONDON, March 24, 2016 PRNewswire -- On behalf of the funds managed by
Paulson & Co. Inc., we own 63,390,111 shares in Premier Foods PLC, more than
7% of the shares outstanding.

We note with concern the announcement today by Nissin Foods Holding Co. that
it has acquired a stake of 17.3% in Premier Foods after earlier signing a
Cooperation Agreement with the Company on Tuesday.

The board has created an environment where they appear to be favouring Nissin
Foods, which paid a significant premium to one shareholder, to the detriment
of all other shareholders who were not offered any premium, and also to the
detriment of other bidders who could be discouraged by Nissin Foods' 17.3%
stake.

We communicated to the Chairman yesterday our belief that after receiving the
approach from McCormick & Co., the Company should fully engage with McCormick.
We also urged him to proactively solicit other offers for the whole Company,
including from Nissin Foods. The fact that the Company's longstanding and
largest shareholder sold all their shares at 63p, shows that the 60p offer
from McCormick should be worthy of engagement.

Refusing to engage is also detrimental to employees and pensioners. McCormick,
an extremely successful US Food Company, has a market value of $12 billion
compared to Premier Foods' market value of $650 million and has far greater
resources to safeguard future pension obligations on behalf of employees.

We believe that only this course of action best fulfills the Board's Fiduciary
and Statutory Duties.

BE

Though let's ignore that Paulson seemed to be trimming its stake at around 40p .....

BE

All the valuation work here is a little stale, but here's SocGen anyway.

11:35 am
BE

Although we expect M&A in the ingredients sector, this proposed deal surprises us. PF
and McCormick both have a presence in the UK Flavours and Seasoning sector (PF’s brands
Oxo and Bisto have around a 40% market share and McCormick’s Schwartz brand a 10%
share), but little else in common, and PF’s high debt and pension fund deficit make it less
desirable in our view. The financial difficulties faced by the company are well documented, and in its statement PF listed several small issues that would negatively affect its year-end position. That said, McCormick’s offer is still at a 15% discount to our index of equivalent Food Producers, and there is the possibility of Nissin getting involved. It is clear that PF was talking to Nissin before McCormick’s first approach, and the agreement for the two companies to work more closely together seems sensible and could at some point in the future lead to Nissin taking a meaningful stake in PF, thus providing a useful backstop.

BE

We think it may be possible for all stakeholders to achieve a compromise and therefore increase our TP to 60p to match McCormick’s conditional bid. However, we consider the prospects of McCormick improving its offer beyond this unlikely. Our previous TP of 40p was reached by applying an EV/EBITDA multiple of 8.5x to CY16e and we used the company’s NPV of cash contributions (£390m) as the best measure of the pension deficit. Our new TP reflects a 50% increase on this, which was always possible with such a highly geared company.

BE

An offer of 60p / share values PF’s equity at £500m, and when the pension fund deficit (which we value at £390m, using the company’s NPV of cash contributions as the best measure) and net debt which we expect to be around £529m at 31 March 2016 are taken into account suggest a total Enterprise value of over £1.4bn – equivalent to 9.6x EBITDA on our forecasts.
Although this is a 15% discount to our index of equivalent Food Producers, there are few
synergies that we can see, and in our view this is potentially a full price for a business with as many challenges as PF has.
The pension fund trustees have negotiated a hard bargain in the past and will be looking to
protect their members should any takeover be agreed. We think it unlikely that they will agree to compromise and this leads us to our conclusion that the current offer price of 60p will not be increased.

BE

Figured it was yet another one of the "two drunks holding each other up" takeovers we're seeing increasingly among the oil smallcaps.

BE

Cantor covers, though, and here they are.

BE

Our View: Cadogan has confirmed that it has made a highly preliminary approach regarding a possible combination with Ascent Resources (AST LN – NC) At this stage there can be no certainty that an offer will be made or as to the terms of any offer. We believe Cadogan’s shares offer investors a compelling opportunity to gain exposure to considerably discounted E&P upside potential, with downside risk mitigated through its strong cash position and natural hedge provided by the company’s new Gas Trading business. We therefore reiterate our BUY recommendation and set a new TP of 36p.

· Further visibility on a potential deal within a month - Cadogan acknowledges that by no later than 5.00pm on 21 April 2016, it must either announce a firm intention to make an offer under Rule 2.7 of the Code or announce that it does not intend to make an offer.

· Complementary acreage – Ascent (market cap: £3.37m) is an independent oil and gas E&P, headquartered in London and listed on AIM, with assets is in Slovenia. Dependency on imported gas is very high throughout the EU, particularly in Slovenia. Its Slovenian operations are in close proximity to existing processing facilities, intra-field and national pipelines, thereby ensuring low-cost connection and easy access to the market.

· Cadogan’s Ukrainian E&P business remains steady - Production has remained steady from Debeslavetska and Cheremkivska (gas) and Monastyretska (oil) licences in Western Ukraine and is currently generating 122boepd net. In order to conserve liquidity, the company does not plan to drill any new wells in 2016, instead re-entering three existing wells in Zagoryanska via its profit sharing agreement at zero cost liability.

· Valuation undemanding - We see the Cadogan’s investment case as representing an attractive opportunity for investors ahead of what we believe could be a transitional year for the company. Even on conservative metrics, we believe our valuation is undemanding, and therefore retain our BUY recommendation and 36p TP.

BE

BE

JP Morgan Cazenove can summarise.

BE

BAG’s FY16 EBIT came in-line with Bloomberg consensus, with 8%
growth in H216 following the challenging H116. BAG’s FY16 sales were
in-line with the FY16 trading update published on 29th January. As usual,
BAG has not provided a formal guidance for FY17, but we do not expect
FY17 consensus estimates to change materially following this update.
With regards to the recently announced plan for a sugar tax, BAG expects
at least c2/3 of its portfolio to be lower or no sugar by April 2018 and
hence exempt from the levy. With the challenges related to the
implementation of the new ERP system behind it, we expect BAG to
return to solid growth in FY17E. BAG remains our top pick in the mid-cap
European Beverages space.
 FY16 results in-line. BAG sales declined by -0.9% yoy to £259m
(FY16 trading update £257m, Bloomberg consensus £258m, JPMe
£257m). Group EBIT was flat yoy at £42.1m (cons £42.1m, JPMe
£42.1m). Following the challenges in H116, EBIT returned to an 8%
growth in H216. EPS were up 5.3% to 29.6p and were ahead of
expectations (cons. 28.0p, JPMe 27.8p) due to lower tax charge
(deferred tax). Net debt at the end of the year was £11.3m (cons £7.7m,
JPMe £0.8m).
 FY17 guidance. As usual BAG has not provided a formal guidance for
FY17. We believe that the tone of the CEO statement is cautious, but we
do not anticipate consensus for FY17E to change at this stage.
 UK Sugar tax. BAG expects at least c2/3 of its portfolio to be lower or
no sugar by April 2018 and hence exempt from the levy.
 BAG remains our top pick in the mid-cap space. We expect BAG to
outperform the UK soft drinks market, as it over-indexes in the high
growth on-the-go vs. the struggling grocery channel. BAG also has
strong brands in high-growth water. Over time, BAG’s profitability will
benefit from its recent ERP system launch. We highlight BAG’s
impressive track record of EBIT CAGR of 12.0% in FY05-FY15.

11:55 am
BE

In addition to Directions of Power over the CCyB the FPC also has powers to direct the regulator to place limits on owner-occupied residential mortgage lending. In June 2014 the FPC recommended mortgage lenders do not extend more than 15% of their total number of new residential mortgages at loan to income ratios at or greater than 4.5. No LTV limits were proposed. In April 2015 legislation was passed to give the FPC power of directions over the owner-occupied residential mortgage market however the same legislation for buy-to-let (BTL) has not been passed. HMT’s consultation on this closed on 17 December 2015. The FPC has noted its concerns around BTL loan growth however in the most recent Financial Stability Report, December 2015, the regulator said greater competition in the BTL sector “has not to date led to a widespread deterioration in underwriting standards of UK banks”. The FPC has previously said the industry’s typical rental cover requirement of 125% is sensible however notes that affordability testing at a mortgage rate of 5-6% is below that of the owner occupied space at around 7%. It is worth noting that the current
recommendation is to stress test affordability if the bank rate were 3 percentage points higher than the rate at origination. If this were extended to the buy-to-let segment we do not think it would significantly impact supply.

BE
